Diary: February 13, Light Rain
With a “bang!,” Mom turned off the TV.
“I knew you’d be watching TV all night! It’s three in the morning. What are you waiting for? For your dad to come back? Men are just emotionless animals!”
Mom fell asleep on the sofa, and I covered her with a blanket. Her heavy makeup hadn’t been washed off. I picked up the three-year anniversary photo on the coffee table; the burn on my hand was clearly visible.
That was my first time trying to make soup. I had never met Dad; Mom seemed more like a child needing care, and I was all she had.
I took off her high heels, tiptoed to her bag, and took out 100 yen. I’ll make Mom egg soup tomorrow; this money is enough to buy two eggs.
Holding the money, I climbed back into bed and set my alarm for an early wake-up.
March 29
This man named Koji seems to really like me and has agreed on a reasonable long-term price. This is the fourth month he’s been giving me money.
Today, he was especially happy.
He wanted to take me for a drive at night. The wind was strong, and as we drove, his phone rang.
After talking for about ten seconds, his expression turned serious. He hung up and immediately turned around, turning into a dark alley.
Suddenly, a mother and daughter appeared in front of the car. He slammed the gas pedal, aiming straight for them. There was a “bang,” and one of them fell.
I was too scared to move. “Did you... did you hit someone??”
He was silent, quickly reversing the car and running over them again. I couldn’t take it anymore and was about to jump out.
He glanced at me, coldly pulled out a stack of dollars, took out a gun, and coldly said, “Choose.”
What should I do? What should I do? What should I do…
April 2
The trial began. As a party involved in the traffic case, I still attended. “I’m sorry, I really need the money. I’m really afraid of dying.”
“I’m just a middle school girl; what can I choose in front of a gun?”
“The brakes were broken; I accidentally hit someone. I can testify.” After saying that, I thought of the scapegoat he arranged for me: “It’s him; he’s the driver.”
I couldn’t look at the wronged man, turning my head away. In the plaintiff's seat, I saw a girl in a wheelchair, wearing a white dress, her lips pale and seemingly weak. But her eyes, filled with resentment and anger, stared at me.
Is she the little girl who survived that day? I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I’m sorry... I couldn’t look her in the face; my face felt hot and painful.
May 14
Summer is approaching, and I’ve moved to a new city. With that money, I attended the best prestigious school in this city for a year and then advanced to the high school section of the prestigious school.
In two years, I’ll have to take the college entrance exam.
I must work hard to learn painting.
Looking at my sketchbook filled with Sailor Moon drawings, flashes of images always appear in my mind: that dim paper, that girl in the white dress in a wheelchair.
I want to be the Sailor Moon who upholds justice, but I ended up becoming the villain who gets defeated by Sailor Moon...
On the last page of my sketchbook, I repeatedly wrote “I’m sorry... but what good is it? What good is it for that girl...?”
I don’t want to be weak anymore. I want to go back. Even if I can’t uphold justice for her, I want to find that old man, even if it’s just to make him pay more so that the girl can live a little better. But where can I find him?
June 1, Sunny to Cloudy
Today is Children’s Day, but Mom won’t be back until midnight.
I watched Sailor Moon on TV; I love them. They can transform and have powerful energy. I silently made a wish: “I want to be Sailor Moon!!”
June 8, Cloudy
I finally contacted Kami; maybe I can get information about that man from her. After a long time, I received a message: “Inari Shrine.”
Perhaps here, I can find the answers I want.
No matter what, I have to find that person.
I packed lightly and walked toward the Inari Shrine.
Since I’m at the shrine, I might as well make a wish. I wished at the shrine: I hope to find that man and help that girl get justice.
Then I aimlessly searched for that man. Just as I reached a big tree, a shrine maiden in a red outfit suddenly jumped out, stared at me, and slowly said, “Go to the Fox Hotel; there you will find the answers you seek.”
Who is she? Should I listen to her?
Where is this place, and what is the Fox Hotel? But now it seems there’s no other choice! No matter; it can’t get any worse. I held the Sailor Moon charm in my hand.
'I'm sorry, this time, I'll muster the courage to seek justice for you!'
August 12
The tuition for the new semester is getting more and more expensive, and I can't bear to ask the neighbor for money again. But the part-time job doesn’t cover it either; looking at the numbers on the blackboard, I don't know what to do.
I sat in the alley smoking, unsure of what to do. If I don’t go to school, I won’t be able to learn to draw. My mind is filled with hand-drawn pictures of Sailor Moon; I want to learn to draw, I want to go to school, even if it’s in this worst middle school.
Jia Mei walked over, her smoky eye makeup particularly heavy today. Blowing smoke rings, she said to me, 'Short on cash? Want a quick way to make money?'
I looked up; her eyes were filled with disdain. She leaned in and whispered, 'Companionship; one night, 10,000 yen. If you do well, you can make quite a bit in one night.'
I looked at her; 10,000 yen—that’s enough to buy the complete set of markers. I clenched my fist and nodded at her.
That night, I followed her to a bar, a hazy atmosphere filled with whistling, arguing, and moaning… until I saw a fat, balding uncle. He approached me, squinting his eyes, scrutinizing my rough hands as he roamed over my body, then pulled out a stack of yen and slapped it on the table.
That was what I wanted! So, I walked into his room…
August 13, sunny
Today, I heard that Miyuko is going to school. She is my neighbor. Shouting loudly, 'This backpack is so ugly! I don't want it!'
I envied her as I picked up the backpack she threw away, wanting to sneak it back. The backpack had my favorite Sailor Moon design on it. Miyuko’s mom came over. 'Nana, do you want to go to school?'
Hearing this, I couldn't help but cry out, nodding through my sobs.
In this slum, everyone knows I don't have a father. My mom is a hostess, and no one has abandoned me; instead, they have always taken care of me.
Miyuko's mom gave me a new backpack and helped me pay the tuition. I can finally go to school!
September 7, cloudy
Today is my first day reporting to middle school.
I chose to sit in the corner; the injury on my hand started to hurt again. That night when my mom came back, she packed up all her luggage. I asked her where she was going.
She patted my head and handed me an envelope.
I opened it to find 600 yen and a letter: 'Nana, take care of yourself. Mom needs someone to take care of her too.' 
She was leaving me. I cried out, grabbing her luggage from her hand. 'Mom…'
A man appeared at the door, balding and hunched over. He rushed up, pushed me aside, and pulled my mom away.
I will never forget, I clutched my mom's hem, begging her not to abandon me, but she got into that man's car without looking back. The injury on my hand began to hurt.
From then on, I knew I would never have even a little bit of spending money. From now on, I had to live on my own.
Go for it, Nana!!!
October 3, light rain
No one likes me; I have no friends, but I don’t care. I have no extracurricular life.
Recently, I need to buy a lot of review materials, so I have to find another job. That way, I can wash dishes during the day and do handicrafts at night to pay for next semester’s tuition in advance.
I’ve already distanced myself from them, so why do they bully me? They cornered me in the girls' restroom, pulling my hair and calling me an unwanted wild child.
They burned my skin with cigarette butts, spat at me, and finally left when they got tired of laughing, cursing, and hitting.
Why am I being bullied even though I’m already so humble? Is it just because I’m different from them?
I envy them for being able to protect themselves and bully others. And I don’t want to be bullied anymore! I want to become like them.
December 20, heavy snow
Life has become a container for me, a living corpse. As soon as school ends, my phone will ring incessantly, and I have to choose one of the numbers to answer.
That’s my source of living expenses.
In addition to markers, I also have new branded clothes, bags, and the complete Sailor Moon set.
Tonight I met a man; his hair was graying at the temples, and he had a big belly, dressed in designer clothes and serious. He’s a company president, supposedly a famous chairman, doing business I don’t understand. His luxury car stopped in front of me, and I hesitated for a moment…

Afraid of that dark gun barrel and his cold, harsh gaze. After steadying yourself, you took a few steps forward to the girl's door; just as you were about to knock, you heard crying from inside. You stopped your hand from knocking and gently pressed it against the door to listen.
You heard the girl inside crying in despair, pounding on something as she shouted, “Why! Why me! Why am I a waste!!! I can’t do anything... Whale, Mom, myself... I can’t do anything right... I can’t protect anything...” You froze; now wasn’t... the right time to go in. The courage you had just mustered vanished in an instant. You fled back to your room like a coward.
Once back in your room, you immediately burrowed into the covers, using the pillow to cover your head, as if this could give you a sense of security. You recalled the words you just heard, filled with regret, guilt, and fear. Your heart was in turmoil; you lamented why, after gathering courage, did you run away? If only you had rushed in to comfort her, if only you could tell her what you had planned... But no matter what, you could no longer lift your feet to go to the place you had just fled from. You hated this weak, timid version of yourself, wrapping yourself tightly in the blanket, hugging your legs and softly sobbing.
You didn’t know how long had passed when you heard a soft knock at the door. You walked over to open it and found it was the Nopperabo. He looked at you with red eyes and asked, “Why are you crying?” Seeing his concerned gaze, you couldn’t help but break down. You cried uncontrollably. The Nopperabo watched you, at a loss, hurriedly pulling an old handkerchief from his pocket and handing it to you, saying, “Don’t cry, don’t cry. Just say what’s bothering you.” You took the handkerchief but didn’t wipe your tears; instead, you burst out laughing, “What era is it? You still carry a handkerchief? Uncle, you’re really outdated.”
Seeing you stabilize your emotions, the Nopperabo sat you down on the bed and asked you to tell him why you were crying. After a long hesitation, you said, “I did something wrong to someone. This matter has tormented me for a long, long time. Ever since then, my life has been filled with guilt. I want to apologize to her, to make up for my mistake, but I lack the courage to face her.” The Nopperabo looked at you seriously and patted your head, saying, “Although I don’t know what you’ve been through, you look like a middle school student. It’s okay to make mistakes; everyone makes mistakes. As long as you realize your error, no matter whether the other party forgives you or not, do your best to make amends. The days ahead won’t be so painful. You’re just a bit scared; it’s okay to not be so brave. Give yourself a little more time to have a good chat with yourself. If you’re not ready now, just have a good sleep, and when the sun rises tomorrow, muster the courage to try again! Just cry a little less in the future; red eyes make you look like a rabbit, and that’s not good.”
You nodded, handed his handkerchief back, and said, “I don’t need this anymore; I won’t cry again.” After saying that, you obediently burrowed back into the blanket.
He watched you lie down and then gently left. You closed your eyes, feeling as if the clouds that had shrouded your heart were beginning to dissipate. If the sun came out tomorrow, would the sunlight really be able to penetrate the clouds in your heart? Lost in thought, you fell into a deep sleep.
